reviewText:
Rememoried is a first-person adventure game, focused on the ideas of dreams and memories with surrealistic, explorative and puzzle-solving settings.

The way you advance in the game is by looking away from your surroundings, elements in the environment, and other important objects for they’ll constantly change shape and create a new path.

“You count the stars above your head just like the one who pointed a finger at you from the unknown. The closer you get to infinity, the more you get lost in the numbers created to describe the real world, and your eyelids become curtains that hide unexpected discoveries beyond the borders, reached by only the strongest thoughts. This exciting play for one spectator is a reward for everyday gifts of the mind.”

The game is visually stunning, along the sound of flowing water combined with the elegant classical and eerie electronic music.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=546692876
This combined with a breathtaking environment makes the game incredibly relaxing if you just explore and don’t focus on the objective.

At times the game can be frustrating or difficult to discover what your objective is for a specific level.
All individually difficult to figure out which requires patience to get into its mechanics yet not impossible to beat them.

But overall, I still had a blast playing through this small indie title. A beautiful game with an equally relaxing soundtrack! Definitely worth a try!

9/10

reviewText:
Rememoried Review in 30 Seconds
https://youtu.be/3HwwDkx0LrI

A surrealist exploration puzzle game where to advance you have to forget. Layers upon layers of dreams and jumbled memories build this stunning dreamscape that goes hand in hand with great music and nice voice acting. In each level you must fulfill a hidden goal that’s only hinted at by the narrator and the scenery itself.

The creative mechanics makes it so that sometimes you must look away from the goal to be able to see it. Sometimes it’s confusing, but so are dreams. Always changing yet still repetitive at times.

7 dreams out of 10.

reviewText:
Summary:Rememoried is a short adventure puzzle game about exploring the surreal world of dreams and memories. You might think this is just another walking simulator without any proper gameplay but you'd be wrong - the game is focused on puzzles and platforming.

All puzzles are based on moving or jumping, there aren't any items to pickup or interact with. You just have to wander through the levels and find the way out. Many environmental elements are usually not stable and (almost) every time you stop looking at a platforms (clouds, for example), they change their positions.

Rememoried isn't just about the gameplay, it's really worth praising the graphics and sounds, the whole atmosphere in most levels will make you often stop and just look around to enjoy what developer's artistic skills made.

Pros:- Well-thought puzzles where you won't get stuck for more than few minutes.
- The world around you changes almost everytime you look to another direction (in levels focused on platforming).
- Great atmosphere. The surreal world of Rememoried is beautiful.
- Nice soundtrack.

Cons:- Short length. Expect getting 100% achievements after 3 hours of gameplay.



Disclaimer: My copy of Rememoried was obtained for free - I won the game in a giveaway that might have been sponsored by the developer. This fact hasn't changed my opinion about the game (and the review) in any way.

reviewText:
PLEASE DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME.

Dont get me wrong: This is one of the most gorgeous games I have ever had the chance to see, and it was a real treat for a while that made it absolutely terrific. And then suddenly? It becomes more rage inducing than any game I have ever played in my life.

This game is essentially pretty precision platformer: the game. The main gameplay mechanic is to basically spin around in a circle over and over to make objects magically move positions in a system the game likes to call forgetting". This ends up being a horrible platformer where you need to spin around in circles to make a platform appear close enough to you so you can land on it
date: and then spin around some more to make another one get closer to you. Some parts of the game aren't like this
hoursPlayed: and honestly fairly enjoyable. But at one point in the game I just could not take it anymore. The platforms were too small
voteText: nearly impossible to see in the dark
helpfulPercent: and I kept falling off of them because they were literally spheres. It was total baloney.\n\nOnce again
votesHelpful: do not get this game. Please watch a dedicated and skilled Let's Player play through the game for you so you have the chance to see how pretty the game can really be. Do not buy this game thinking it will be some zen experience worthwhile of your time. The developers wanted it to be zen-like
votesFunny: but allow me to tell you that when you're stuck in one area for far too long
commentsCount: it is not worth that "zen-like" feeling.\n\n3/10
column16: pretty graphics and cinematography at least. This was a game designed by a brilliant artist...but not a brilliant game designer."

reviewText:
Rememored is a very brief, yet amazing dreamlike experience.
There´'s little in therms of gameplay, but the whole experience feels like a psychedelic dream, even if mostly black and white.
You are led into an exploration adventure inside an illogical, yet magical world and the atmosphere, mixed with the incredibly good music, engages the player on a sub-concious level.
Each small level you are constantly willing to go on, just to experience the next amazing set piece the developers have prepared.
Highly recommended if you like experimental videogames.
If you like gameplay-heavy games stay away (the game only asks to navigate the environments and do some basic platforming).

reviewText:
This game baffles me. I'm not sure quite how to feel about it.

It's visually stunning and the music / audio is great. I've completed the game and struggled on at least 3 levels, one being the last level. I'm unsure if I missed a narrative queue here and there, but I got frustrated a bit.

It was a relief to finish it, and I ended up going back again and doing some of the levels again.

Would I recommend it? I'm voting yes...however, I like the 'odd' type of game, so it fits with who I am as a gamer. It may not be for everyone, but if you're up for a unique experience, give it a whirl.

reviewText:
A Surreal Exploration Adventure Gamehttps://youtu.be/Y6hT8tU2FqY
+ Very unique and interesting levels/environments that tries to break through the realm of imagination
+ A interesting game mechanic where the level will literally change every time you look away except for what you are standing on.
+ Relaxing soundtrack

- Very limited amounts of color, mostly black and white
- This game made me nauseous as you are constantly required to either spin in circles or look down, and when you look back up parts of the level changes. Mix that with some extremely bright white lights and random screen tearing and you may get a headache.
- The level where you are jumping on cloud to try to get to the top ladder is absolutely horrendous...not only do you have no idea where or what to do the platforming can be so iffy" at times causing you to miss jumps that look in your reach.
- Most levels do not tell you what or where to go so you really need to use a guide to make any sort of progress


Even though I felt nauseating at times
date: the game gives a unique experience and certainly worthy to try out."

reviewText: This is a really tremendous walking sim. It reminds me a bit of Lemma, except (mostly) without parkour. When you first load the game it feels like a pure walking sim in the vein of Proteus because the place is so beautiful and the music is outstanding. It's a delight just to wander about. After a while you start to realize there is some logic in the game and some puzzles to figure out. Most of the puzzles are exploratory, but there are one or two insanely frustrating jumping puzzles that almost had me giving up altogether. Jumping puzzles aside, this is a stunningly gorgeous game with some really cool mechanics and well worth a look for anyone into walking sims or art games.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
OK, so I finished the game (rather, I finished the last level - you will see what I mean, if you play it) and I don't know how I did it. You see, I tried that level many times with no avail. But just now, I went at it again and finished it in 30 seconds. I would like to load it up again and see how I did it, but this game has no such options.
If you think this situation is weird, well, you've seen nothing yet. This game has some of the most creative and bizarre walking (or, should I say, finding) levels you are ever likely to see. The one with the segmented world falling apart is simply breathtaking, although really short. These walking levels are intertwined with some of the most irritating and psychotic platforming sections found in gaming.
I'd say this game fits in the same category as works of art like Naissancee and Mind: Path to Thalmus, yet is not like those games in any regard, if that makes sense.
Not for everyone, but a milestone nevertheless.

reviewText: Very enjoyable game. There used to be one really annoying thing that after you made a mistake you had to play the previous level again, but that's fixed now, you can kill yourself as many times as you like and start the same level again without penalties, much more fun that way :)\n\nSurreal atmosphere, things change when you are not looking at them, great graphics. I don't like reverb in the vocals that much, but you don't have to re-play previous levels so I can live with that. If you like Dear Esther, this is definitely a game for you. If you only play FPS, don't even bother. Have fun!

reviewText:
This game has some very distinct strengths and weaknesses, which makes me a bit hesitant to recommend it. I go into more detail in my full written review[feedmepixels.com] (Minor puzzle spoilers, but I personally think you'd thank me). The video at the top of the page illustrates some of my problems with the platforming.

Pros:

-Good sound design
-Great visuals
-Beautiful, abstract aesthetic

Cons:

-Repetitive, RNG dependent mechanic that is present through the whole game
-Difficult to discern if some platforms would take you where you want to go or take you further away
-Sometimes arbitrary, impossible to guess objectives. Sometimes just tripping over the thing you need is the only way to proceed.

Overall, I personally feel the cons outweigh the pros since your enjoyment of one is almost completely reliant on the other.

reviewText:
I'm a pretty big fan of this sort of game but I can't recommend this one.

The graphics are OK in general and some scenes look quite good but you will spend most of your time just wandering around looking for a random object, or continaully spinning around to make platforms spawn in the right place (they appear or disapear while not looking). Those mechanics are reused many times and it just makes for a tedious experience overall.

Then there is the dialogue which is essentially nonsense. It sounds like they think it's deep but you just can't take it seriously with comments like Space is dogma. Dogma is logic" or "Space and time are just definitions".

When you do finish a level it just fades into the next one
date: often before you actually reach the thing you're trying to get to. It leaves you without any real sense of achievement.\n\nSo while I wanted to like this game

reviewText: No. Don't buy it.\nThe graphics are nicely done, and the basic gameplay idea might be interesting, but overall the experience is poorly designed. For the first three levels it's even interesting to explore some obscure landscapes of procedurally-generated rocks, but then it's just it. The game becomes really frustrating as it goes on, and repeating the same game mechanics just makes it worse. Add some annoying music that loops forever and you get the most stressful game that I have ever played. Maybe it's the intention of the developer, but it would be lame to do so. In my own opinion it's just a bad experiment that has some really good ideas inside. I think just watching the trailer is enough.\n

reviewText:
My experience with this game was strange. I spent the most time on the first level and the last level. I have no idea exactly how long I played it for, as my actual time lies, I left the game running for a while in between play sessions, thinking I'd only be gone so long. After level one I found the game to be much easier,  and stranger. I think because I spent so much time in level one, I got a little too attached and even scared of the thing that brings you to the next level.

The game itself is like a 2 hourish walk through several strange worlds. I equate it to a dream because most individuals report dreaming  in black and white, however with the few instances of gorgeous color this game fits the description of a dream itself. The game itself is rather fun, there is one blaring issue that comes to mind, which is present in plenty of indie titles and that is the reliance on one major mechanic to tell the story. In fez it was world flipping, in this game it is 'forgetting' you basically look away from the platforms until they move to your liking, when you're looking at them they don't change. To progress through the game you must walk over to a specific point or do something specific in the almost uninteractive environment. Uninteractive doesn't necessarily mean bad for this game as it isn't necessary a puzzle game, more of a goal understanding with you looking for a focal point in a level and then finding your way over.

If I had to improve the game (and probably my review here) I'd do a few things, make it either less or more deep, and probably add more variety in puzzles. I found myself frequently flicking my mouse back and forth to change my stepping stones or to look for something changing by the end of the game.

If I had to give it a score I'd say 7.5 to 8.5 out of ten. I think the creator's message was a bit lost on me, and was probably too deep in general. However the enviroments themselves are georgous. This is a great game for that friend who loves all his indie hits, is looking for a gift or if you can get it on sale I'd recommend it.

pro tip to ESL / no english developers. use your original language with subtitles. srsly the voice acting and writing is BAD. moving on, a couple hours of some slightly novel but not particularly interest game mechanic - look away and the world will introduce new platform elements (forgetting and remembering sort of).
